H0.text: Axis is the line along which the distribution of body parts is balanced in the symmetrical body plan of animals, except for sponges.

H1.text: Skull is the reference point along which the animal body plan is symmetrical, meaning the distribution of body parts is balanced along it, as animals are classified by morphological and developmental characteristics such as body plan, with sponges being the exception.

H2.text: Radius is the axis along which the distribution of body parts is balanced in the symmetrical animal body plan, with the exception of sponges.

H3.text: Ulna is the axis along which the distribution of body parts is balanced in animals, except sponges, because their body plan is symmetrical.

A4.text: Animals with bilateral symmetry have an anteriorâ€“posterior (AP) axis which runs from the head or mouth to the tail.

A5.text: While sponges and placozoans represent two groups of animals which do not show any symmetry (i.e. are asymmetrical), the body plans of most multicellular organisms exhibit, and are defined by, some form of symmetry.
